node.title: How one woman's struggle with mental health created a safer space for others
node.description: In 2003, Michelle Banfield left an emergency department untreated and without a mental health diagnosis. Now, she's establishing a 'Safe Haven' for people to talk about their own mental health.
node.content:
["Michelle Banfield's favourite place in the world is the chook shed in the backyard of her home in\u00a0Murrumbateman, just outside Canberra.", "The paddock, where her four alpacas roam, comes a very close second.", "\"My animals are probably my chief therapy, if you like,\" Ms Banfield said.", "\"I'm surrounded by them and they maintain a level of calm in me.", "But knowing what she needs for her mental health\u00a0is a long way from where the Australian National University academic was, at age 27.", "", "
Michelle Banfield was taken to hospital by a friend in 2003, who recognised that she was suicidal.(Supplied: ANU/Tracey Nearmy)
", "After a fraught solo trip to Peru, Ms Banfield withdrew from her PhD studies at the ANU and found her mental health deteriorating.", "\"I kind of hit that crisis point about January in 2003, when I was like, 'Well, nothing I wanted to do, nothing I planned to do, nothing I had worked to do was actually going to come, so maybe I shouldn't be here anymore,\" she said.", "A friend recognised that Ms Banfield was suicidal and took her to the emergency department.", "\"Emergency departments are not somewhere that people who are experiencing extreme emotional problems should actually be,\" Ms Banfield said.", "\"They're overwhelming for anybody who is there, let alone somebody who needs space to talk to someone \u2013 they're just not set up for that kind of thing.\"", "The hospital staff completed a number of assessments and sent Ms Banfield\u00a0home\u00a0untreated.", "Eventually, she found the help \u2013 and the bipolar diagnosis \u2013 she needed elsewhere.", "But the experience sparked a drive to help shape a space that catered exactly to the needs of Canberrans who felt as helpless as she had.", "", "
The ACT government's Safe Haven room where people can access mental health support.\u00a0(Supplied: Facebook)
", "
'Pivotal' spaces provide support from peers
", "The now-mental health researcher helped to create Safe Haven, a hub opening today at the Belconnen Community Health Centre in Canberra.", "The space is one of four similar \"locally responsive\" spaces in Australia\u00a0\u2013 the others are located\u00a0in Wollongong, Blacktown and Campbelltown\u00a0\u2013\u00a0and there are plans to establish another\u00a0in South Australia\u00a0early next year.", "Safe Haven in Canberra, which is funded by the ACT government, will work in tandem with local health services but is mostly a place\u00a0where people can speak to trained staff who have faced their own mental health challenges, like Ben Martin.", "", "
Peer mental health worker Ben Martin.(ABC News: Rosie King)
", "\"I've got a diagnosis of bipolar and that started rearing its heard when I was 23 or 24,\" the peer worker said.", "Mr Martin has been motivated to help others struggling with their mental health ever since his diagnosis, and said the power of shared experience could not be underestimated.", "\"It can be really pivotal,\" he said.", "\"You get so used to talking to clinicians, doctors, psychologists and they're not usually able to draw on their own experiences, even if they have some themselves.", "", "
ACT Mental Health Minister Emma Davidson is hopeful Safe Haven can help reduce demand for existing services.(ABC News: Antoinette Radford)
", "Part of the aim of Safe Haven is to reduce the pressure on existing mental health services in Canberra, including emergency departments, which are notoriously overburdened.", "\"It provides an opportunity for people to seek help at an earlier point in their mental health journey, so before they reach the kind of crisis where they need to go to emergency or have an in-patient stay,\" ACT Mental Health Minister Emma Davidson said.", "\"Having a service like the Safe Haven available to help people connect with the right service for where they're at is really going to help people to get into a recovery space sooner and stay in that recovery space for longer.", "\"That's the great thing about working with peer mental health workers \u2013 they can help you navigate the mental health system to find the right service at the earliest point.\"", "As for Ms Banfield, she said opening up was critical to getting her on the path to recovery.", "\"There is so much to be said for sharing,\" she said.", "\"Having a shared experience, an understanding that somebody is not there to fix you, they're there to hear you, walk beside you and to just listen empathically to what you're going through is absolutely invaluable.\""]
